clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of a TDM Program for Intensive Care Patients in the Cerebrospinal Fluid
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of a TDM Program for Intensive Care Patients in the Cerebrospinal

brief_summary.textblock: Therapeutic drug monitoring of antibiotics in critically ill patients is a present research topic of the last ten years. Research results have shown subtherapeutic blood concentrations in those patients. However, the amount of antibiotics in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in patients with ventriculitis or meningitis is still unclear. This study is a prospective study to evaluate the concentration of different antibiotics in the CSF in patients with an external ventricular drainage compared to antibiotic blood concentration.

detailed_description.textblock: Bacterial infections are still associated with a high mortality in intensive care unit patients. Especially patients diagnosed with ventriculitis caused by a bacterial infection have a bad outcome. Therefore, antibiotic therapy is the only causal opportunity to treat those infections. However, there are many chances in pharmacokinetic and -dynamic in critically ill patients with unpredictable antibiotic concentrations. Furthermore, it is important that the concentration in the blood as well as in the effect-compartment "CSF" is sufficient. Less data of the last years describe antibiotic concentrations in the CSF and show subtherapeutic levels, which is endangering for the therapeutic success. The introduced study is a prospective, observational study that analyses antibiotic concentrations in CSF in critically ill patients. The distribution between CSF and blood will be evaluated by comparing these two compartments.

primary_outcome.measure: Incidence of subtherapeutic antibiotic concentrations in cerebrospinal fluid
primary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion, on average 2 years
primary_outcome.description: Percentage of subtherapeutic concentrations of different antibiotics in different subgroups like ventriculitis vs. no ventriculitis

secondary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion, on average 2 years
secondary_outcome.description: evaluation of the 28-day mortality in patients with therapeutic and subtherapeutic antibiotic concentrations in cerebrospinal fluid

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation of antibiotic concentration in cerebrospinal fluid and C-reactive protein
secondary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion, on average 2 years
secondary_outcome.description: Correlation of different antibiotic concentrations in patients´ blood and cerebrospinal fluid and the C-reactive protein in the blood. Question of interest is, if therapeutic antibiotic concentration leads to a faster decrease of C-reactive protein

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation of antibiotic concentration in cerebrospinal fluid and interleucin 6
secondary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion, on average 2 years
secondary_outcome.description: Correlation of different antibiotic concentrations in patients´ blood and cerebrospinal fluid and the interleucin 6 in the blood. Question of interest is, if therapeutic antibiotic concentration leads to a faster decrease of interleucin 6

study_pop.textblock: critically ill patients with an external ventricular drainage and the need of antibiotic therapy

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- written approval of the legal guardian
- external ventricular drainage
- antibiotic therapy
Exclusion Criteria:
- no approval
- no antibiotic therapy or no external ventricular drainage
